headline.main: Today in Politics: Immigration Ruling Stymies Obama and Those Seeking His Job

docs.abstract: President Obama’s lawyers acknowledged that his executive actions on behalf of undocumented immigrants could be blocked by legal fights until nearly the end of his presidency, potentially robbing him of an achievement that could be part of his legacy.

docs.lead_paragraph: A skeptical federal judge grilled Obama administration lawyers Thursday over the House GOP's health care lawsuit, sounding unlikely to side with the president and dismiss the case.

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal health officials announced the new guidelines after a clinical trial showed pronounced benefits for people put on antiretroviral drugs as soon as they learned they were infected.

headline.main: H.I.V. Treatment Should Start at Diagnosis, U.S. Health Officials Say
headline.print_headline: Scientists Urge a Prompt Start of H.I.V. Drugs

docs.abstract: Federal health officials recommend people infected with HIV be immediately put on antiretroviral drugs upon diagnosis, since those who receive immediate treatment are 53 percent less likely to develop AIDS or serious illness; halt clinical trial on early treatment led by National Institute for Allergy and Infectious Disease because results were overwhelmingly clear.
docs.snippet: Federal health officials announced the new guidelines after a clinical trial showed pronounced benefits for people put on antiretroviral drugs as soon as they learned they were infected.

keywords.value: National Institute for Allergy and Infectious Disease (NIAID)
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: A Burmese woman working in Thailand hired a man to sedate and smuggle her 3-month-old baby across the border to relatives in Myanmar, researchers said, describing a common "service" for desperate migrant mothers fearful of losing their jobs.

headline.main: Desperate Migrant Pays for Baby to Be Drugged, Smuggled to Myanmar: Researchers

headline.main: Bernie Sanders Challenges Hillary Clinton at His First Rally

docs.lead_paragraph: A Supreme Court ruling due in a few weeks could wipe out health insurance for millions of people covered by President Barack Obama's health care law. But it's Republicans — not White House officials — who have been talking about damage control.

docs.lead_paragraph: An appropriations bill is no place for major changes to trucking regulations.

headline.main: A Foolish Attempt to Weaken Truck Safety
headline.print_headline: A Foolish Attempt to Weaken Truck Safety

docs.abstract: Editorial criticizes appropriations bill that is larded with concessions to trucking industry by Republican lawmakers, many of which make trucking more dangerous; warns lawmakers against weakening regulation of industry, citing 17 percent increase in number of people who have died in accidents involving trucks between 2009 and 2013.
docs.snippet: An appropriations bill is no place for major changes to trucking regulations.
